div1.p: Sierra Leone District Yearly Report Henry Rider

Consular Agent Freeform the port of entry for the Colony of Sierra Leone West Africa, lies in 1842 N. and 13 14' /8. It is a place of some note and has been burned the metropolis oof this particular part of the coast. The port contains some six or seven thousand inhab -itants and the census taken before the late epidemic returns nearly forty thousand people in the colony. The exports of the place are ground nuts, hides, palm oil, camwood, , palm kernels, beeswax, ivory and native gold. Ground nuts and find their principal market in France and are almost wholy shipped in French bottoms, palm oil, palm kernels, and bees-wax, are also shipped to France but in smaller quantities. Palm-oil and hides are the principal exports to the United States, besides which small quantities of groundnut, camwood and ivory are occasionally shipped, these freight are confined to

to American vessels. England presents a market for all the exports of the colony in a quart- er or less degree. The imports are Tobacco in hogshead, rum, provisions, and a few dry goods, from the United States, dry goods and provisions of every description from England dry goods, mints, and liquors, from France. The port does not present a flourishing cena- -dition, on the contray a stranger is im- pressed with the streets are grass-grown with but little havel through them and there are dilapidated houses, and lots overrun with weeds to be met with at every step; the black population, with some exceptions, are very poor and inactive, preferring to remain about town earning perhaps enough for a single meal, to living in the village and cultiva- ting the land, which with a moderate amount of labor would remumerate them kandsomely; the exceptions are generally liberated Africans, who by strict economy and much shrewdness have accumalted money and are, with the few Europeans, the business men of the place, the apathy before spoken of horroer, is entirely

enitrely confined to apperance, for the commer- cial interests of the place are of considerable importance, the reverence have increased steadily for some years past a corresponding increase in the commerce of the colony, the a- mount of business done with United States is not inconsiderable as the following returns for 1859 wil show
Total of American importations $20,209.14.1 . " " 0/0 . exportations $50,202.17. The returns for 1860 I have not been able to obtain.

The commerce with France is much more important than that of the United States, and the business done with England is very great, beside many sailing vessels there is a monthly line of Steamers freighting and these cannot supply the demand of the port for English good, most every packet leaves merchandise behind for want

want of room. A serious drawback to the rapid growth of the colony, and a heavy burden on the merchants is the very high tariff of duties imposed upon goods impor- ted, many tons of merchandise are now taken to the rivers, which with a mere liberal tariff would find their way direct to Freetown, enclosed I for- ward a copy of the table of duties. Vessels pay a homage duty of one shilling and six pence and have the priveledge of leaving and returning to the port a number of times in the same voyager providing they are not absent over two months at any one time, a further charge of three pence a ton is collected as light dues vessels are also subject to a harbor masters fee of one pound sterling for vessels of 100 to 150 tons, and ten shillings for each 50 tons over.

The currency of the colony is that of England, the sterling pounds, shillings, and pence, all dollars (silver) are current at par value. Spanish and American gold pass at a small disent, French treaty frame pieces command a small premium but all other French gold is wholly uncurrent.
This port is a coaling station for English

English steamers cruising about the vieinity, in on their passage to other stations down the coast, and quite a large amount of homage is en- gaged in bringing the coats, the vessels generally proeuring freight of African timber from the adjacent rivers as return cargoes. The slavers taken as prizes by English cruisers are sent here for condemnations, the following, is a list of those comdemned during the latter part of last year and for the present year up to date. 1st Sept 29th 1859, a brig name unknown, arri- ved with 469 slaves on board, she was captured off hydah by C.M.88. "Spitfire" commander Chapman; condemned by the Vice Admirally court; about 300 of the slaves were shipped on boards thhe bark "Many Sim" Henton Master, emigrant ship bound for Trinnidad, she sailed from this port June 19th 1860. It is reported that many of the slaves left against their will, and that a number of them where let out of the yard in which they had been kept, 10 go on board the vessel, escaped to the bush, but were recaptured, the un- willingness to leave is accounted for in this way, the slaves found many entry men

countrymen among the people of Sierra Leone who persuaded them they ought to remain, and not allow themselves to be sent away. It seem the better plan to send them away however, as in nine cases out of ten they turn out very bad if allowed to remain in the colony.

Long NoN. arrival here April 17th 1860, the ship was without papers, or names condemned in the Vice Admirally court. 4th Bark "Cortances" under Urigarayan colrs formerly the American bark "HopingCloud") captured by H.M.S.S.'Elect' off Camroons, arrival here October 3rd 1860 condemned in thr mixed com= mpion court October 29th 1860 as a prize to England and the Urignayan Republic.

last vessel up to this date (December 26th 1860).
A canoe was captured by Thomas Sike Eqre harbor master, off Tagreen point Sierra Leone river on the night of Feburary 21st 1860 she had on board 34 slaves they were all liberated.

Of Cafe, Bulame, in the Rio Grande river has occupied the attention of this government, it is considered a dependent of this colony, it has been visited lately by Governor + Cill, and he will attempt another settlement, a company of soldiers are to the stationed there at once. The Portuguese also claim the island and occupied it until driven out by the English the claim I believe has never been property settled. In the spring and sum- mer of 1859 an epidemic visited the colony, causing about, empty deaths out of a population of one hundred Europeans, the place is but just recovering from the effects of it.
